Surrounded by rolling hills & vineyards, St. James is a unique #MO city. Hope you enjoyed learning more! #MissouriSpotlight

As you can see, there’s lots to see & do in Bethany. Thanks for joining us for this week’s #MissouriSpotlight!
Today, w/ the fundraising help of local Girl Scouts, there is a mural dedicated to Babe Adams: http://www.bethanymo.com/pView.aspx?id=1919&catid=70 … #MissouriSpotlight
Fun Fact: Babe Adams, who played for the Pittsburgh Pirates & pitched in two World Series games, lived in Bethany. #MissouriSpotlight
Bethany is graced with many older homes, including the 1882 Cuddy Home. Open for tours on Sundays in June & July. #MissouriSpotlight

Bethany is a haven for outdoor enthusiasts, with Dunn Ranch Prairie minutes away: http://www.nature.org/ourinitiatives/regions/northamerica/unitedstates/missouri/dunn-ranch-prairie.xml … #MissouriSpotlight
With a population of 3,000 – healthcare, retail trade, agriculture & education make up the economic base of Bethany. #MissouriSpotlight
A city consisting of 4.48 square miles, Bethany is located on I-35 directly between Kansas City & Des Moines, Iowa. #MissouriSpotlight
The 1st home in Bethany was built by John S. Allen. It was used to store the 1st stock of goods brought to the community. #MissouriSpotlight
Originally named Dallas, court & county officials in 1860, w/ the approval of residents, changed it to Bethany. #MissouriSpotlight
In the 1840s, many of the early pioneers of Harrison County settled along Sugar Creek and in the Bethany area. #MissouriSpotlight
Today’s #MissouriSpotlight is headed NW to Bethany, the county seat of Harrison County! http://www.bethanymo.com pic.twitter.com/ik88KwfKop

Claire: I’m eager to get a better sense of what Congress can do to combat these scams. Continue watching LIVE: http://www.aging.senate.gov/hearings/virtual-victims-when-computer-tech-support-becomes-a-scam …
Claire: I’m pleased Lew Polivick from Legal Services of Southern #MO is here today to talk about his work w/ seniors. #ProtectSeniors
Claire: In southern #MO, leaders from groups have come together to fight fraud. Legal Services of Southern #MO is leading the charge.
Claire: But collaboration b/w consumer educators & law enforcement will make it much less likely a criminal will succeed. #ProtectSeniors
Claire: So what can be done here? Consumer education helps, for sure. As does more robust law enforcement. #ProtectSeniors
Claire: Tech scams are on the rise & fighting them won’t be easy. These bad actors can work from anywhere w/ a computer. #ProtectSeniors
Claire: Not only do these scammers charge for “services,” they get access to personal data, which can lead to more crimes. #ProtectSeniors
Claire: It makes sense these fraudsters would cling to a senior’s insecurity abt technology, under the guise of assistance. #ProtectSeniors
Claire: They’re confidence scams, pure & simple. If there’s 1 thing many seniors aren’t confident about, it’s technology. #ProtectSeniors
Happening Now: Claire's taking a closer look at tech-support scams targeting seniors. Watch LIVE: http://www.aging.senate.gov/  #ProtectSeniors

Tech-support scams get victims to pay for “tech support,” while taking over their computer to steal personal information. #ProtectSeniors
Tech-support scams come in many forms, including calls to potential victims or alarming messages warning of a ‘virus.’ #ProtectSeniors
From January to August of this year, the @FTC received 19,000 tech-support complaints. #ProtectSeniors
Tech-support scams have emerged over the past few years & the @FTC has put them in their own category of fraud. #ProtectSeniors

Today @ 2:30pm ET, Claire will look at how tech-support scams are harming seniors. Watch live: http://www.aging.senate.gov/hearings/virtual-victims-when-computer-tech-support-becomes-a-scam … #ProtectSeniors

Whether it’s shopping, sight-seeing or outdoor adventures, the @CityofNeosho has it all! Take time to visit this week’s #MissouriSpotlight.
Today, much of downtown @CityofNeosho is on the National Register of Historic Places & has undergone a revitalization. #MissouriSpotlight
Painter Thomas Hart Benton was born in Neosho & as a teenager was a cartoonist for the @JoplinGlobe 30 mi NW of Neosho. #MissouriSpotlight
During WWII, the @CityofNeosho was home to Camp Crowder - soldiers including Dick Van Dyke were stationed there. #MissouriSpotlight
Fun fact: @CityofNeosho is also known as the “Flower Box City,” & colorful flower boxes adorn many businesses & homes. #MissouriSpotlight
The National Fish Hatchery in the @CityofNeosho is the oldest operating federal fish hatchery. #MissouriSpotlightpic.twitter.com/6QJOsuMUgu

60 mi west of Springfield, @CityofNeosho was founded in 1833 by English, Scottish, German & Welsh settlers. #MissouriSpotlight
.@CityofNeosho’s name is of Native American derivation meaning “clear or abundant water” & 9 springs are in city limits #MissouriSpotlight
The most populous city & county seat of Newton County, @CityofNeosho is home to nearly 12k ppl. #MissouriSpotlightpic.twitter.com/IPCo3hDa2y

Weston is also home to Snow Creek, where Missourians can ski, tube & snowboard all winter long. #MissouriSpotlight http://skisnowcreek.com/
The Weston Historical Museum has artifacts from prehistoric days in Platte County to post WWII. #MissouriSpotlight http://www.westonhistoricalmuseum.org/
If you love Christmas decor, Weston’s the place for you! Each Dec. candlelight tours are led through historic homes. #MissouriSpotlight
Hike & bike Weston Bend State Park, where the scenic overlook lets you see the #MO River as Lewis & Clark did. #MissouriSpotlight
Weston is home to McCormick Distilling Co., oldest whiskey distillery west of the Mississippi #MissouriSpotlight http://www.mccormickdistilling.com/content/history.php …
Weston Brewing Co. was one of the first U.S. large breweries. Opened in 1842 & reopened in 2005. #MissouriSpotlight http://www.westonirish.com/
Weston was a major starting point for the Santa Fe & Oregon Trails & CA Gold Rush. It saw its heyday b/w 1837-1860 #MissouriSpotlight
Weston was the farthest “west town”–last place wagons could stock b/f crossing the river-until the admission of Texas. #MissouriSpotlight
Located on the #MO River, Lewis & Clark camped in Weston where today’s city hall sits. They declared it beautiful! #MissouriSpotlight

As you celebrate America’s Independence, take in the sights & historical attractions the @CityofIndepMO has to offer. #MissouriSpotlight
Today, @CityofIndepMO, east of KC, maintains a vibrant town square w/ many city originals: http://www.visitindependence.com/real-independence/independence-originals/ … #MissouriSpotlight
In addition to Truman’s Presidential Library, the @CityofIndepMO continues to shine a light on his lasting legacy #MissouriSpotlight
During Truman’s presidency, their home in @CityofIndepMO served as the “Summer White House.” #MissouriSpotlightpic.twitter.com/R3UEIJt4D2
Truman & his wife Bess, who was raised there, are buried in @CityofIndepMO. Visit their old home: http://www.nps.gov/hstr/the-truman-home.htm … #MissouriSpotlight
.@PresHarryTruman grew-up in the @CityofIndepMO & after serving two terms as President, returned there until his death. #MissouriSpotlight
In addition to Trails Museum, you can find the ONLY hair museum in the world in @CityofIndepMO: http://www.leilashairmuseum.net/  #MissouriSpotlight
Today, in the @CityofIndepMO you can visit the National Frontier Trails Museum: http://www.visitindependence.com/listings/National-Frontier-Trails-Museum/33/ … #MissouriSpotlight
.@CityofIndepMO – “Queen City of the Trails” – was the jumping off point for the California, Oregon & Santa Fe Trails #MissouriSpotlight
.@CityofIndepMO – farthest point westward on the #MO River where steamboats could travel – was a prime trading point #MissouriSpotlight
Named for the Declaration of Independence, the city was founded on March 29, 1827 & quickly became a major frontier town #MissouriSpotlight
Hometown of President Harry Truman, @CityofIndepMO is also home to over 120,000 ppl, making it #MO’s 4th largest city. #MissouriSpotlight

If you happen to visit Eminence (we recommend you do) take them up on their motto to “stay a day or a lifetime” #MissouriSpotlight
Eminence also has a downtown full of quaint shops, locally-owned restaurants & places to stay or camp. #MissouriSpotlight
County seat of Shannon County, it’s now home to largest organized trail ride & declared “one of the Ozarks’ treasures” #MissouriSpotlight
Early on Eminence experienced a boom when #MO Mining & Lumber had a sawmill in town & even boasted a pop. of 12K ppl! #MissouriSpotlight
Eminence was founded as a frontier town, but was burned during the civil war & later moved to its current location #MissouriSpotlight

In the “Heart of the Ozarks,” Eminence is home to 600 ppl & during Summer attracts visitors from #MO’s national park #MissouriSpotlight
Summer in Eminence is busy. Known as the “Canoe Capital of the World,” ppl can float on the Jacks Fork & Current Rivers #MissouriSpotlight

Thanks for letting us shine the #MissouriSpotlight on a “wonderful, warm community” w/ a Peculiar name! Join us again next week.
30 miles from downtown Kansas City, Peculiar boasts, “a wonderful, warm community, w/ a ‘small town’ feel” #MissouriSpotlight
Peculiar-approx 8 sq mi-has a Downtown Arts & Culture District, awarded a “#MO Creative Community” #MissouriSpotlight http://www.downtownpeculiar.com/index.cfm
Early settlers came to Peculiar by riverboat and rail & the town was est. in 1868 & reestablished in 1889. #MissouriSpotlight
You can read all about how Peculiar got its name on the city’s website: http://www.cityofpeculiar.com/pView.aspx?id=6747&catid=587 … #MissouriSpotlight
(3/3)The postmaster wrote back “My conclusion…it would be difficult to imagine a more distinctive name than Peculiar" #MissouriSpotlight
(2/3)The 3 names were rejected, so they wrote “We don’t care what name you give us, so long as it’s sort of peculiar” #MissouriSpotlight
It’s said that when early settlers were deciding on a name, they sent 3 to the post office for consideration. #MissouriSpotlight (1/3)
Peculiar’s name attracts a lot of attention, including the @USNews list of “Strangest Town Names” http://travel.usnews.com/features/Americas_Strangest_Town_Names/ … #MissouriSpotlight
Peculiar – located in Cass County – is home to apprx. 4,000 ppl & goes by the motto “Where the ‘odds’ are with you” #MissouriSpotlight

Claire: #MO’s Attorney General got 50x the # of complaints for illegal telemarking calls than for the next highest category of complaint.
Claire: We must give law enforcement more tools & flexibility to fight these fraudsters, b/c the complaints are only increasing. #robocalls
Clare: We have to stay on top of this issue - spammers & robocallers use whatever tools available to defraud American consumers. #robocalls
(3/3) Claire: This bill would allow @FCC to enforce our spoofing laws against overseas callers who direct activities to the U.S.
(2/3) Claire: The bill would give @FCC more authority, allowing it to go after non-licensed #robocall violators & increasing penalties
Claire: This week I introduced the #Robocall and Call Spoofing Enforcement Improvements Act of 2015 w/ Chairman @SenatorCollins (1/3)
Claire: I’m pleased the @FCC heard our concerns & offered a proposal for companies to begin offering tools to combat unwanted #robocalls
Claire: Today, #MO Attorney General Joe Dandurand joins us to explain why consumers need power & choice for which calls they receive
Claire: That does not sit well w/ me - or #MO’s Attorney General, who led a letter to the FCC to clarify if companies were being truthful
Claire: Innovators have made great strides w/ call-blocking technology, but company reps insist the law does not allow them to do this
Claire: I’ve been tough on phone companies not b/c they cause the problem, but b/c they are perhaps in best position to do something.
Claire: When I talk with Missourians I often hear from them about these unwanted #robocalls

Chillicothe’s – incorporated 1851 – proximity to transpo routes made it a livestock & agricultural trading center #MissouriSpotlight
Each outdoor mural in @VisitChilli, “transports the viewer into a by-gone era”: http://www.chillicothecity.org/murals.html  #MissouriSpotlight
In downtown @VisitChilli, you’ll find a series of outdoor murals & each celebrates a piece of the town’s history. #MissouriSpotlight
Chillicothe comes from Shawnee language for “big town” & named after their Chillicothe – 1 mile from present-day city. #MissouriSpotlight

We’re glad to shine the #MissouriSpotlight this week on the charming, small #Missouri town: Tightwad!
Tightwad often attracts attention, including a 1988 @LATimes story about MO’s unique places #MissouriSpotlighthttp://articles.latimes.com/1988-05-29/news/vw-5667_1_missouri-towns …
As Tightwad Bank told the @WashingtonPost: “We're seeking the customers with a sense of humor” #MissouriSpotlighthttp://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/08/17/AR2008081702195.html …
Speaking of the Tightwad Bank – reopened in 2008 – it caught notoriety based on its name. #MissouriSpotlight
As of 2010, Tightwad had a bank, a café, a tavern and a convenience store in their business district. #MissouriSpotlight
Tightwad’s name is said to come from a store owner charging a postman $.50 extra for a better watermelon in early 1900s #MissouriSpotlight
Located in western Henry County, the small village of Tightwad is home to approx. 60 people. #MissouriSpotlightpic.twitter.com/ir6qQjuFz9
The town and its 1 sq mile of land, has been known for its sense of humor with street names like ‘Stingy’ & ‘Miser’ #MissouriSpotlight

.@WhitemanSpirit came to the area in 1942 & named after the 1st member of armed forces to die in aerial combat in WWII. #MissouriSpotlight
By 1870s, Knob Noster was described as "the boomingest settlement in the county," b/c of vast coal deposits in the area #MissouriSpotlight
This city – 60 miles east of Kansas City – began in 1850 when a post office was established. #MissouriSpotlight http://knobnostergov.com/history.html
Knob Noster has two hills NE of town called knobs & combined w/ noster (Latin for “our”) is how the town got its name. #MissouriSpotlight
Knob Noster – located in Johnson County – is home to over 2,700 ppl who live only 2 miles from @whitemanspirit. #MissouriSpotlight

The @CityofLebanon has a lot to offer & Claire was proud to call it home. Thanks for joining in our #MissouriSpotlight this week!
Today @CityofLebanon is home to 14,000 people & approx. 1 mil visitors who enjoy this town on the edge of the Ozarks. #MissouriSpotlight
The @CityofLebanon – close to Bennett Spring State Park – attracts trout fisherman taking in the current season. #MissouriSpotlight
The @CityofLebanon’s magnetic waters were said to have healing powers & visitors came to drink and bathe in the water. #MissouriSpotlight
Unique Fact: In 1889 a worker digging a new well in @CityofLebanon found the water had magnetized his tools #MissouriSpotlight
The railroad came to Lebanon in 1868 & served as a boost to the city’s economy by attracting commerce to the rural area #MissouriSpotlight
The @CityofLebanon’s name came from one of its leading citizens, Rev. Benjamin Hooker’s hometown in Tennessee #MissouriSpotlight
Lebanon, located in Laclede County, was established in 1849 and became a #Missouri 4th Class City on October 17, 1877 #MissouriSpotlight
Claire’s family moved to the @CityofLebanon shortly after she was born, where her family ran the corner drug store. #MissouriSpotlight

#PCAPact brings local officials into the process, imposes minimum training requirements & improves data on use of military-grade weapons.
#PCAPact reforms fed programs to strengthen oversight & coordination when giving equipment, funds to local law enforcement.

That's all the #Veterans Day facts for today! To learn more: http://bit.ly/bVOKsv Thank you to all our brave veterans!
Fact #5: It wasn’t until 1978 when the gov’t began observing the #Veterans Day we know today.
Fact #5: On Sept. 20, 1975 Pres. Ford signed a law which returned the annual observance of #Veterans Day to the original date of Nov. 11.
Fact #4: In 1958, the Uniform Holiday Bill moved #Veterans Day to a Monday in Nov. Many did not agree and continued to practice on Nov. 11
Fact #3: In 1938, Nov 11 was officially made a legal holiday, but at the time it was to be celebrated and known as "Armistice Day” #Veterans
Fact #2: In November 1919, President Wilson declared Nov. 11 as the first commemoration of Armistice Day. #Veterans
Veterans Day falls on Nov 11 every year b/c WWI armistice fell on this day in 1918. It was regarded as the end of “the war to end all wars.”
As we observe Veterans Day tomorrow, here's a few facts as to why Nov. 11 is the day we honor our brave #veterans.
